fields.description:
h3. *+Background+*

Vendor's P2 plugin bundles lots of font files that their app asynchronously loads, and they want Confluence to serve them with gzip compression.

The font files are JavaScript files, but they don't have an extension.

They were hoping to be able to make Confluence/Tomcat interpret them as {{application/javascript}} and serve them gzipped by specifying this parameter:
{code:java}
        <resource type="download" name="fonts/" location="/fonts">
             <param key="content-type" value="application/javascript"/>
        </resource>
{code}
The [documentation|https://developer.atlassian.com/server/confluence/adding-plugin-and-module-resources/#values-for-param-element] suggests that this should work, but it doesn't for them.
h3. *+Workaround+*

They have enabled HTTP compression in Confluence

Example resource definition:
{code:java}
    <web-resource key="lucid-confluence-resources" name="lucid-confluence Web Resources">
        <resource type="download" name="images/" location="/images"/>
        <resource type="download" name="fonts/" location="/fonts"/>
        <context>lucid-confluence</context>
    </web-resource>
{code}
Example path to an individual file:
{code:java}
resources/fonts/bundles/0c/c5/c5/39/20/f8/61/fd/fe/4a/b4/be/11/4c/f0/68/fallback/BasicLatin
{code}
Note that the file BasicLatin has no extension, so Tomcat is unable to determine its MIME type automatically, so it won't serve it compressed (instead it serves the file with a generic Content-Type {{application/octet-stream;charset=UTF-8}}).

They ended up going through two iterations of solutions:
 1. Renamed all font files and added a .js extension to them (e.g. BasicLatin.js). After the change Tomcat began serving the files gzipped with Content-Type: application/javascript. Change the application code to use the updated URLs.
 2. Vendor agrees that serving resources pre-compressed is even better. But again, Confluence's plugin framework doesn't make that straightforward. They ended up compressing all the font files with Brotli compression and implementing a custom Servlet that either serves the pre-compressed font files as is (with correct HTTP headers) or decompresses them on the fly if the browser doesn't support Brotli compression (e.g. IE11).

Serving static files via a custom servlet adds some overhead unfortunately (compared with serving them via an efficient static file web server), but it was still a net win overall for them.
h3. *+Suggested Solution+*

Confluence plugin framework should automatically handle serving pre-compressed static resources in the following way:
 * It should correctly detect the original MIME type of the files and have the ability to have it specified explicitly in atlassian-plugin.xml
 * It should support serving pre-compressed files with either gzip or brotli encoding and automatically decompress the files for clients that don't support them
 * If a pre-compressed resource has a filename of resources/fonts/BasicLatin.br, it should be accessible via HTTP at <plugin_resources_base_url>/fonts/BasicLatin (without the .br extension) so that I don't have to change client-side application code depending on the content encoding

h3. Notes
 * [Compressing an HTTP response with Confluence|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/compressing-an-http-response-within-confluence-13204.html]
 * [Adding plugin and module resources|https://developer.atlassian.com/server/confluence/adding-plugin-and-module-resources/#values-for-param-element]
 * Supporting Ticket: [https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/DEVHELP-1054]
 * App Total Installs: *767* affected customers
fields.summary: Improve MIME type handling in descriptor, support pre-compressed resources, and improve resource namespace mapping

h2. Problem Summary
If the "Confluence JIRA Plugin" is disabled for whatever reason, the Confluence Editor will break in various ways:
* If Collaborative Editing is enabled, the Editor title and body fields cannot be clicked on
* If Collaborative Editing is disabled, the Editor will load for existing pages, but for new pages only the title field can be filled in

Additionally, this failure does not produce any sort of errors in the logs or in the UI, which leads to difficult troubleshooting.

# Install Confluence and from scratch with Collaborative Editing enabled
# Go to Confluence Admin > Manage Add-ons and set the dropdown to "All add-ons"
# Locate the "Confluence JIRA Macro" (plugin key: confluence.extra.jira) and Disable it
# Try to create or edit a page

h2. Expected Behavior
* Either the editor will work, OR it will spit out an error indicating that a dependent component is disabled.
* Secondly, the Confluence logs should print something specific which points to the Confluence JIRA Macro being disabled.

h2. Actual behavior
Title and Body fields in the Editor cannot be clicked on. There are no errors in the UI nor the Confluence logs.

h2. Resolution
Enable the "Confluence JIRA Macro" plugin. See this KB for details

h2. Related KB
https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/editor-does-not-work-properly-315326472.html

fields.description:
Confluence synchronization with the AD will remove any occurrence of duplicated groups in the AD tree with the following example message, even if the group is on different locations of the AD tree.
{code:java}
WARN [Caesium-1-1] [atlassian.crowd.model.DirectoryEntities] filterOutDuplicates entity [GROUPNAME] of type LDAPGroupWithAttributes duplicated in remote directory. Ignoring all occurrences.
{code}
This message occurs for each duplicated group found and the application will remove all occurrences of the group during the sync.

If you are using the "Update group memberships when logging in" for "every time the user login in", the application will add the group into Confluence groups during the user login action, removing the group again on the subsequent synchronization causing the strange symptom of losing and gaining permissions regularly.
h4. Expected results

Confluence should merge all occurrences of duplicated groups, aggregating each group members into a singular group on Confluence UI.
h4. Workaround

The only known workaround is to write up a [group filter|https://confluence.atlassian.com/kb/how-to-write-ldap-search-filters-792496933.html] and filter the duplicated groups out of the sync. Since the groups have the same name, you must filter using an attribute that differs them to take effect.
fields.summary: Duplicated groups in AD are removed from Confluence after synchronization

h3. Summary

We cannot type Japanese characters correctly in a table with Chrome 65+ in case that the more left cell is not empty.

Japanese character is generally composed of consonant+vowel letter combination like "k" + "i" = "き" and Japanese IME helps the conversion.
 However, such conversion doesn't work as expected in the specific condition.

Also, this problem is not reproducible with Chrome v63 and the prior versions. This problem might be related to some spec change in Chrome.
h3. Environment

Client that runs the browser is
 * Windows and macOS
 * Chrome (Tested with ver. 65.0.3325.162)
 * Microsoft IME (Japanese) , Google Japanese IME, and Mac IME (Japanese) (This means this occurs in any IME.)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a blank page.
 # Create a table with more than two columns.
 # Type some character (e.g. "a") in a cell in the first column.
 !screenshot-3.png|thumbnail!
 # Set IME to Japanese.
 # Try to type some Japanese character (e.g. "き") in a cell more right from the cell in Step 3.
 (i) You need to type "k" + "i" in order to compose the Japanese character "き".

h3. Expected Results

"k" + "i" should be always converted to "き" with Japanese IME. ("ki" = "き" in Japanese)
 [^Firefox.mov]
h3. Actual Results

"k" + "i" becomes "kい". The initial consonant letter is auto-committed. ("i" = "い" in Japanese)
 !screenshot-4.png|thumbnail! 
 [^GoogleIME.mov] 
 [^MicrosoftIME.mov]
h3. Notes
 * Please note this symptom is different from the issue CONFSERVER-54326 because it reports that first letter is "ignored" while the letter is "auto-committed" in this case.
 * This occurs only at the Chrome environment, and IE11 also has another issue(Cannot type double byte characters in Section through IE11). Firefox works fine.
 * As mentioning in the above, this problem might be related to some spec change in Chrome.
 ** This has not occurred on Chrome v63.x and prior.
 ** The very similar behavior can be seen in different products (e.g. Slack) aside from Atlassian's ones
 *** [Latest Chrome 65 update breaks start of CJK IME input · Issue #2009 · quilljs/quill · GitHub|https://github.com/quilljs/quill/issues/2009]
 *** [576573 - Japanese IME: First character is auto-committed on office extensions - chromium - Monorail|https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=576573] (This is a bit old report, however still opened.)
 *** [Google Groups – Chrome 65 アップデート後 Slack で一文字目が意図せず確定される問題について|https://productforums.google.com/forum/#!topic/chrome-ja/toeoosmoBdo]

h3. Workaround
 * Delete the affected letter, and re-type the contents.
 * Use Firefox browser.
fields.summary: Unable to type Japanese characters correctly in a table with Chrome 65+ in case that the more left cell is not empty

fields.description:
We have noticed in testing that there are some logging improvements that Synchrony Data Center requires some additional logging capability beyond its current form. This is by no means an exhaustive list, but the main points are included below:
 * Database port connection check
 ** If Synchrony is unable to connect to the database port, it will still start up anyway. It will not log any failures to either the Synchrony logs on the Confluence nodes or on the Synchrony Data Center nodes.
 * Database bind credentials check
 ** If Synchrony's startup script does not contain a valid database username/password then the startup will fail and the process will exit without a clear reason.
 * Version checks of Synchrony JAR and Database JAR
 ** On startup, Synchrony does not post what version of Synchrony is running, nor the database driver it is using. We would like to have this included in startup logs.
 * JWT Key check
 ** Synchrony requires JWT keys to startup properly. If they are not defined in environment variables or in the startup script, the startup will fail and the process will exit without a clear reason.
 * Cluster node connection type not logged
 ** On startup, Synchrony does not post the type of connection it is anticipating (tcpip, aws, or multicast). It also does not log if none of these are properly defined, or there is an error in the definitions.
 * MD5 Mismatch
 ** Synchrony will still startup if its MD5 does not match if the JAR is malformed.
 * Other generic script errors
 ** A malformed startup script can start up as long as the RUNJAVA details are correct for the Synchrony JAR, but will not function properly in the Confluence UI. No log output will mention missing variables or other malformed startup parameters.
fields.summary: Synchrony Startup Logging Improvements

h2. Summary
Without a thorough understanding of bash scripting, as well as taking the time to analyze and modify the [^start-synchrony.sh] script located in {{<confluence-install>/bin/synchrony}} which ships with the product, Synchrony will not work as intended using the default values. 

When attempting to start the Synchrony service via {{start-synchrony.sh}}, the process cannot connect to the database and thus Collaborative Editing will not work. 

This is due to the following line being commented out in the script:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
# SYNCHRONY_OPTS="${SYNCHRONY_OPTS} -Dsynchrony.database.password=${DATABASE_PASSWORD}"
{code}

While the database username and password are declared in the script, the password will not be passed to the Synchrony process while the above line is commented out.

h2. Important Details
This occurs regardless of whether you have declared the database username and password in these two lines:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
# Your Confluence database information (can be copied from confluence.cfg.xml in your Confluence home directory)
DATABASE_URL="<YOUR_DATABASE_URL>"
DATABASE_USER="<DB_USERNAME>"
{code}

Additionally, this also occurs regardless of whether you have elected to use the synchronyenv file as noted here:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
# # Uncomment this section to specify an executable shell script to source for environment variables
# # Useful for passing sensitive information (i.e. passwords) to Synchrony
# # Use this method when setting environment variables for Synchrony running as a service
# # Example of file contents:
# #	 	export SYNCHRONY_DATABASE_USERNAME="<DB_USERNAME>"
# #		export SYNCHRONY_DATABASE_PASSWORD="<DB_PASSWORD>"
# SYNCHRONY_ENV_FILE="<PATH_TO_ENV_FILE>"
{code}

h2. Environment
* Affects Confluence Data Center 6.5.x & 6.6.x
* Does not apply to Confluence DC 6.4.x and prior
* Does not apply to Confluence Server Standalone 

h2. Expected Results
Synchrony will successfully start and Collaborative Editing can be enabled.

h2. Actual Results
The synchrony process will start and then die, preventing Collabortive Editing from working properly.

h2. Workaround
Uncomment the following line in the script:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
# SYNCHRONY_OPTS="${SYNCHRONY_OPTS} -Dsynchrony.database.password=${DATABASE_PASSWORD}"
{code}

Example:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
SYNCHRONY_OPTS="${SYNCHRONY_OPTS} -Dsynchrony.database.password=${DATABASE_PASSWORD}"
{code}
fields.summary: Commented password variable in start-synchrony.sh script prevents Synchrony from successfully starting

Since Confluence 6.1, Data Center has stored a copy of the confluence.cfg.xml in the shared home directory, to simplify booting new cluster nodes in AWS and Azure deployments. Upgrading a Data Center install since this release does not trigger upgrades of this xml file, which can lead to new nodes having an old build number in their local home directory (since they copy the file from shared home as part of their initial setup process). This in turn can lead to fast-failing upgrades later, due to the 3-way validation check on the build number in the local home directory, and the database, and the code being deployed.

Confluence must update the xml file in the shared home after any upgrade tasks are executed - ideally by the node that executes database upgrade tasks.
h3. Workaround

After completing an upgrade on a single node, the system administrator can manually copy the confluence.cfg.xml from a properly upgraded local home into the shared home. This will ensure that further fresh nodes will have an upgraded configuration.
fields.summary: Upgrade of cluster install does not upgrade build number in shared home confluence.cfg.xml
